image.altText: Men and children hold containers as they line up for water

items.synopsis: The head of the UN agency for Palestinians expresses growing concern for the lack of clean water in Gaza, while Israelis living near the UN-patrolled Lebanese border evacuate from villages as tensions rise. Follow live.

title.children: Concerns over lack of clean water in Gaza Strip, Israelis evacuate from Lebanon border

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's military says it has killed four people who tried to cross the fence bordering Lebanon and plant an explosive device on Tuesday. In an update posted online, the Israel Defense Forces said the four people were part of a "terrorist squad". Its update did not include further details. It comes after increasing cross-border fire between Israel and the Lebanese Shiite militia, Hezbollah. Yesterday, the Israeli military ordered people living in 28 communities near the border to evacuate. ABC with Reuters and AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel's military says it has killed four 'terrorists' near border with Lebanon

children.content: Israel's military says it has killed four people who tried to cross the fence bordering Lebanon and plant an explosive device on Tuesday.
In an update posted online, the Israel Defense Forces said the four people were part of a "terrorist squad".
Its update did not include further details.
It
comes after increasing cross-border fire between Israel and the Lebanese Shiite militia, Hezbollah.
Yesterday, the Israeli military ordered people living in 28 communities near the border to evacuate.
ABC with Reuters and AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Buses for Australians seeking to leave the occupied West Bank have been delayed. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade had arranged chartered buses to transport Australian citizens from the Palestinian city of Ramallah to Jordan. It is unclear why the buses have been called off. Officials are working to enable transport through the Allenby Bridge crossing which connects the West Bank and Jordan. Numerous Australian repatriation flights have departed Ben Gurion Airport in Tel Aviv over recent days however travel in, out and around the West Bank involves passing through Israeli military checkpoints and presents risks and complications for dual nationals.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Delays getting Australians out of West Bank

children.content: Buses for Australians seeking to leave the occupied West Bank have been delayed.
The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade had arranged chartered buses to transport Australian citizens from the Palestinian city of Ramallah to Jordan.
It is unclear why the buses have been called off.
Officials are working to enable transport through the Allenby Bridge crossing which connects the West Bank and Jordan.

Numerous Australian repatriation flights have departed Ben Gurion Airport in Tel Aviv over recent days however travel in, out and around the West Bank involves passing through Israeli military checkpoints and presents risks and complications for dual nationals.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hundreds of Israelis have left villages and kibbutzim near the tense, UN-patrolled frontier with Lebanon following cross-border fire that has become more deadly as tensions have heightened. While thousands of people have died in southern Israel and the Gaza Strip since Hamas's October 7 attacks, recent violence in the north has also claimed lives — two in Israel and at least 11 in Lebanon. Since the Hamas attacks, "everything has changed," said evacuated kibbutz member Lea Raivitz, 68, still stunned by the onslaught. One day after the shock attack, her kibbutz Bar'am, located right by the Lebanese border, moved out with all its people — from newborns to those aged in their 90s — in only its second evacuation since it was founded in 1949. "It's shaken all of our beliefs," Raivitz told AFP, speaking at their temporary new home, a hotel in Tiberias on the western shores of the Sea of Galilee. Communities within 2 kilometres of the Lebanese border were evacuated to state-funded guesthouses on Monday. The Israel-Lebanon border area has remained largely at peace since a devastating war in 2006 between Israel and Hezbollah. Residents of kibbutz Bar'am who have lived there for decades say that unrest over the years has come in cycles, and they are used to seeing Hezbollah posts and flags from their homes on the other side of the border. But some told AFP that their sense of security had been all but shattered following the October 7 rampage by Hamas, the worst attack in the country's history. "We're all traumatised, we're all scared," said kibbutz resident Angela Yantian, 67. "I didn't think that sort of thing could have ever happened." Some kibbutzniks said Israel's sacrifice and the fight ahead are worth it if they bring greater security for Israel in the future. "Every terror organisation needs to know that we will deal with them when the time is right for us," said Tsachi Shaked, 51. "If the right time is now, then we will need to do it now." AFP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Shaken beliefs': Israelis evacuate from tense Lebanon border

children.content: Hundreds of Israelis have left villages and kibbutzim near the tense, UN-patrolled frontier with Lebanon following cross-border fire that has become more deadly as tensions have heightened.

While thousands of people have died in southern Israel and the Gaza Strip since Hamas's October 7 attacks, recent violence in the north has also claimed lives — two in Israel and at least 11 in Lebanon.
Since the Hamas attacks, "everything has changed," said evacuated kibbutz member Lea Raivitz, 68, still stunned by the onslaught.

One day after the shock attack, her kibbutz Bar'am, located right by the Lebanese border, moved out with all its people — from newborns to those aged in their 90s — in only its second evacuation since it was founded in 1949.
"It's shaken all of our beliefs," Raivitz told AFP, speaking at their temporary new home, a hotel in Tiberias on the western shores of the Sea of Galilee.

props.alt: Five soldiers in front of a tent.

children.content: (AP: Francisco Seco)
Communities within 2 kilometres of the Lebanese border were evacuated to state-funded guesthouses on Monday.
The Israel-Lebanon border area has remained largely at peace since a devastating war in 2006 between Israel and Hezbollah.

Residents of kibbutz Bar'am who have lived there for decades say that unrest over the years has come in cycles, and they are used to seeing Hezbollah posts and flags from their homes on the other side of the border.
But some told AFP that their sense of security had been all but shattered following the October 7 rampage by Hamas, the worst attack in the country's history.
"We're all traumatised, we're all scared," said kibbutz resident Angela Yantian, 67. "I didn't think that sort of thing could have ever happened."
Some kibbutzniks said Israel's sacrifice and the fight ahead are worth it if they bring greater security for Israel in the future.
"Every terror organisation needs to know that we will deal with them when the time is right for us," said Tsachi Shaked, 51.
"If the right time is now, then we will need to do it now."
AFP

image.altText: A woman wearing a long grey coat walks past reporters and a camera operator

items.synopsis: A failed South Australian Senate candidate and anti-vaccine protester standing trial for assaulting a female police officer will argue she was attempting to free herself from an "unlawful" arrest, a court hears.

title.children: Woman accused of 'pulling actual clumps of hair' out of police officer's scalp pleads not guilty

image.altText: A man with a beard and wearing a suit jacket.

items.synopsis: Muslim community leader Ahmed Zreika quits his board membership with the SA Multicultural Commission in protest against the state government's stance on the Israel-Gaza war, which he says has been characterised by anti-Palestinian bias.

title.children: Multicultural leader quits over SA government's response to Israel-Gaza war

image.altText: Peter Greste speaking at the National Press Club

items.synopsis: An Australian journalist who spent 400 days imprisoned in an Egyptian jail on terrorism charges is calling for media freedom to be enshrined in Australia's constitution — but concedes it's unlikely to ever eventuate.

title.children: Peter Greste wants a Media Freedom Act, but doubts Australians can be convinced

image.altText: Couple standing on a rocky landscape.

items.synopsis: Blake Jory grew up in Noosa. Last year on a European holiday, he fell in love with an Israeli woman. Now he's experienced war firsthand and his partner is soon off to the front line.

title.children: Australian man's romance lands him in the middle of Israel-Gaza war

image.altText: A defaced electoral sign.

items.synopsis: Of the many lessons of Saturday's referendum on the Voice to Parliament, there is one which must be more urgently addressed — our appetite for mistruths, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: With the lies and disinformation of Voice referendum exposed, Australia is sleepwalking towards the future

image.altText: a woman in a gamer tshirt looking at the camera

items.synopsis: Chantal Ryan, who will speak at international convention South by Southwest, is using her platform to inspire and support other women to get involved in gaming.

title.children: More diversity needed in booming gaming industry, Adelaide designer says

image.altText: An aboriginal woman wearing a white singlet standing inside a house.

items.synopsis: South Australian Aboriginal leaders are calling for the community to learn from the referendum result and come together following the campaign.

title.children: No SA federal electorate is projected to have voted Yes. Here's how Aboriginal leaders are responding

image.altText: A bushfire emits an eerie glow in the night sky.

items.synopsis: Residents of northern NSW are struggling through a second day of severe bushfires, with two blazes at Watch and Act level and a fire at Byron Bay inching closer to homes.

title.children: Bushfire situation in NSW escalates as fire crews wait for easing conditions

image.altText: The main street of a rural town

items.synopsis: The resounding No vote in Western Australia has been met with relief by many who say it was a distraction, including those in the Wheatbelt town of Darkan. But others say there will be ramifications for reconciliation.

title.children: Almost 90 per cent of people in this WA farming town voted No. Here's why

image.altText: Vladimir Putin emerges from a pack of men in suits, looking proud of himself

items.synopsis: Vladimir Putin is making a rare visit to China for his "dear friend" Xi Jinping's Belt and Road summit. Seen as something of a social pariah on the global stage, and facing war crimes charges over his assault on Ukraine, what do he and Xi stand to gain from this visit?

title.children: Putin has landed in one of the only places he won't be arrested. Here's what he and Xi could be looking to achieve

image.altText: A man stares down the barrel of a camera while sitting in a room, wearing all black.

items.synopsis: Alex Ophel, who is facing two charges of attempted murder for allegedly stabbing two women at the Australian National University, will undergo psychiatric assessment before his case returns to court.

title.children: Canberra man facing two attempted murder charges for alleged ANU stabbing to undergo psychiatric assessment

image.altText: The outside of the Toowoomba Court

items.synopsis: Lawyers for a high-profile man charged with rape west of Brisbane have formally appealed a court's decision to allow his identity to be revealed

title.children: Judge grants stay of non-publication order for high-profile man accused of rape in Toowoomba

image.altText: Pro-Palestinian protesters are seen during a rally in Hyde Park Sydney. Palestinian flag in centre of frame

items.synopsis: A 63-year-old man is arrested in Sydney's west after allegedly making offensive comments at the rally in Hyde Park at the weekend.

title.children: Man charged over 'offensive language' at Sydney pro-Palestinian rally

image.altText: A person with dark skin wearing a beanie with their head resting in a their hand.

items.synopsis: The grief-stricken grandmothers of a First Nations teenager clinging to life after apparently trying to take his own life inside a notorious youth detention unit say they feel like he was "sent to a big meat house and came back slaughtered".

title.children: 'He had dreams': Heartbroken family of 16yo on life support say he just wanted to return home

image.altText: a bushfire at night, with the whole scene lit up red, sparks flying.

items.synopsis: Backburns have been put in place with the aim of stopping the fire before it moves from scrubland into the Barkly's open plains, which are some of the NT's most productive cattle country.

title.children: Hopes backburning will slow NT fire that has burnt more than 2.8 million hectares

image.altText: NSW Premier Chris Minns and Federal Minister for Indigenous Australians Linda Burney pictured at a Voice polling booth in Sydney

items.synopsis: While New South Wales has the biggest Indigenous population, it's the only state or territory not to have already started the treaty process. So what might a treaty look like in the state and what happens from here?

title.children: NSW will push on with First Nations treaty despite Voice referendum's defeat. Here's what it means

image.altText: A photo of a young boy in a broken frame, draped in a Western Bulldogs scarf

items.synopsis: Adam Kneale has accused the Western Bulldogs of turning a blind eye to a sexual predator who preyed on young boys at the club four decades ago.

title.children: Victim of historical sexual abuse sues Western Bulldogs for damages

image.altText: The front of a ruined house

items.synopsis: The community of Kfar Aza was among the prime targets when Hamas terrorists stormed into Israel. More than a week later, dead bodies and explosives still litter the streets.

title.children: Children's bicycles and dead bodies: What this Israeli town is like a week after Hamas's attack

image.altText: Soccer fans in Belgian flags in the stands of a stadium. A man and woman hugging tightly

items.synopsis: Amateur videos show a man with a large weapon shooting several times near a station.

title.children: International football match abandoned after two Swedes shot dead in suspected terror attack in Belgium

image.altText: A black and white image of a crowd with a teenage Natalie in the front, looking up at the stage

items.synopsis: Natalie Imbruglia's childhood dream was to become a star. While realising that dream brought unexpected curve balls, she says she wouldn't do anything differently.

title.children: How one of Australia's biggest pop exports plotted her journey from girl in the INXS crowd to star on stage

image.altText: Jack Ginnivan holds a medal between his teeth

items.synopsis: A deadline day move for Jack Ginnivan could be on the cards with Hawthorn waiting in the wings, while Paddy Dow and Nick Coffield secure deals late in the penultimate day of the AFL trade period.

title.children: Pies premiership favourite eyes Hawks switch, multi-club deal breaks AFL trade logjam

image.altText: An older man wearing a dark suit chews his nails as he suits at a small cafe table

items.synopsis: Former inmate Trudy Sheiles tells an inquiry she didn't report being sexually assaulted by a senior NSW prison officer because she was "terrified of the repercussions".

title.children: Threats of violence and 'repercussions' prevented inmate from reporting prison officer’s abuse, inquiry told

image.altText: A young, fair-haired girl lies intubated a hospital bed, holding an ice block, while her mum sits smiling beside her.

items.synopsis: A Newcastle woman whose daughter spent a month in hospital after having life-saving surgery is urging people to be aware of the hidden danger a common cleaning tool can pose.

title.children: How eating a bacon-and-egg roll left 9yo girl needing life-saving surgery — and it could happen to anyone

image.altText: blowfly

items.synopsis: Early warm weather has triggered a bumper season for Australia's 30,000 fly species. So who are these curious insects, and how should we think about their presence in our lives?

title.children: With fly season underway in Australia, get to know our most common species and how to keep them away

image.altText: A small blue and white home sit in a green backyard. it has open white french doors.

items.synopsis: Advocates say it could help ease pressure from historic low vacancy rates of less than 1 per cent, which have left people scrambling for affordable rentals.

title.children: More than 600,000 homes in Australia are suitable for granny flats. Analysts say they hold 'untapped potential'

image.altText: An old brick motel in Canberra's north

items.synopsis: An ACT Supreme Court Justice labels the task of sentencing a man cleared of rape as an "extraordinary injustice" after fresh admissions he had sex with the victim despite previously denying all allegations.

title.children: 'Extraordinary injustice': Canberra man found not guilty of rape admits to having sex with victim despite previous denial

image.altText: A soldier in military uniform and helmet looks out from a covered position, as sun shines in through holes in a camouflage tarp

items.synopsis: Ukraine says Russia is running out of steam in some areas, but fighting in other locations has "significantly escalated".

title.children: Russia's invasion of Ukraine reaches 600 days, as fighting escalates in key areas

image.altText: Two people peer into a thin hiking tent set up on grass in the shade of trees

items.synopsis: Outreach workers Ada Watson and Ayden McMahon are at the coalface of the homelessness crisis, watching over rough sleepers and working to help the desperate and the vulnerable.

title.children: Compassion, solace and a barbecue — on the frontline with the guardian angels of the rough sleepers

image.altText: girl in tent

items.synopsis: Sixteen-year-old Maddison's family pays $360 a week to live in a tent after having to move out of their rental home when it went up for sale. The teenager has big dreams, but she worries about her future.

title.children: Maddison and her family live in a tent. Her parents say they can't afford the fuel to drive her to school

image.altText: A man and woman look at paperwork while sitting at an outdoor wooden table

items.synopsis: The competition between mortgage lenders to get your business could soon be heating up again, analysts say, as the nation's largest lender loses market share for the first time in five years.

title.children: Will we soon see 'mortgage wars' part two as the nation's biggest bank bleeds customers?

image.altText: An old colour photo of a young man sitting in bushland with no shirt on

items.synopsis: For more than two years, Shane Tapp's family has pushed for more information surrounding his death by the Katherine River in the Northern Territory.

title.children: 'A human being that deserved better': Shane Tapp's family hope inquest will deliver answers

image.altText: A peregrine falcon in a nest box feeds her two fluffy white chicks.

items.synopsis: For the past 15 years, falcon lovers around the world have watched on with joy and at times heartbreak at the private lives of a peregrine falcon family live streamed for a university project.

title.children: 'No filter, no editing': Global audience hooked as falcon family welcomes new chicks
